head.title: Springsteen and the Message of 'American Skin'

hedline.hl1: Springsteen and the Message of 'American Skin'

abstract.p: Seth Kerschner letter on John Tierney The Bity City June 14 column on controversy over Bruce Springsteen's new song American Skin, which deals with fatal police shooting of Amadou Diallo; says Tierney oversimplified meaning of song; says song deals with issues like urban paranoia, race, and fear and confusion that many police officers face on the streets

block.p: Re ''Has the Boss Joined Ranks With the Limousine Liberals?'', by John Tierney (Big City column, June 14):
Re ''Has the Boss Joined Ranks With the Limousine Liberals?'', by John Tierney (Big City column, June 14):

I am a Bruce Springsteen fan who attended the Monday night concert at which ''American Skin'' was played. Mr. Tierney oversimplified the meaning of the song, saying Mr. Springsteen's message is that ''it is a really bad idea for police officers to kill an innocent man'' and that ''it is a really, really bad idea if the killing involves multiple discharges of bullets.''
The song, which is about the tragic killing of Amadou Diallo, deals with much larger issues, like urban paranoia, race, and the fear and confusion that many police officers face on the streets.

Mr. Tierney assumes that Mr. Springsteen is attacking the four officers who shot Mr. Diallo 41 times, suggesting that Mr. Springsteen might have been expected to take the side of the officers, who were ''working-class guys trying to do their jobs while oppressed by larger social forces.''
That description seems to fit Mr. Diallo as well. But the only difference between him and the officers is that the larger social forces resulted in Mr. Diallo's death.
